Introduction

The average rate of survival following CPR is relatively low although the proportion varies considerably depending on different factors. The rate of survival is even lower for patients with serious underlying conditions and it may not be in their best interests to attempt CPR. Not addressing resuscitation could deny patients of a dignified death and subject them to intensive treatment at the end of their life.

The guidelines ‘Decisions Relating to Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation' (2016) was jointly published by the British Medical Association, Resuscitation Council UK and Royal College of Nursing (previously known as the ‘Joint Statement'). It identifies the increasing importance of multidisciplinary team working by acknowledging that it may be suitable for some experienced nurses and Allied Health Professional's (AHP's) to lead DNACPR discussions as part of advance care planning.
Scope
This purpose of this document is to:
Support the pilot of ‘universal' uDNACPR discussions and decisions
Support related advance care planning (treatment escalation plans)
Provide guidance to experienced nurses and allied health professionals regarding their roles and responsibilities when undertaking DNACPR discussions
Outline the training required to be deemed competent to make DNACPR decisions
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
Resuscitation and Deteriorating Patient Committee – is responsible for the review and approval of this procedure; and the monitoring of resuscitation audit reports.
Information Governance Committee (IGC) – is responsible for the receipt and monitoring of annual audits of clinical record keeping.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer the Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Medical Director
The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that all appropriate hospital medical staff are aware of their responsibilities for the implementation and monitoring of this policy.
Consultant in charge of patient's care

The Consultant in charge should be made aware of the DNACPR decision however the experienced nurse or allied health professional can make the overall decision and do not require a senior doctor verification. If a Consultant has concerns about the decision made, they should discuss them with the accountable healthcare professional concerned and seek advice if appropriate (ethics, legal, etc).
Director of Nursing

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that all competent experienced nurses and allied healthcare professionals are aware of their responsibilities for the implementation and monitoring of this policy. Also the Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the division and that competency records and a central register of trained healthcare professionals are held within the Trusts (usually delegated to the Palliative Care Team).
Experienced Nurses or Allied Health Professionals

Whether or not to attempt CPR is a part of the patient management plan. Some experienced nurses or AHP's may be suitable to undertake DNACPR discussions for their patients in conjunction with Advance Care Planning, however they should not be called upon to make decisions in acute sudden events. The health professional must have completed the appropriate training and deemed competent.
To ensure appropriate decision making regarding DNACPR the health professional must:
Be competent to make the decision and be able to make a best interest decision
Make every effort to involve the patient (where appropriate) in discussions and consider their wishes
Take into account the patient's mental capacity and any advanced decisions to refuse treatment

If the patient lacks capacity the patient's next of kin/relatives/Lasting Power of Attorney should be asked if the patient had made previous decisions regarding resuscitation and involve them in the decision-making discussion
Where the patient lacks capacity and/or has nobody to speak on their behalf then an Independent Mental Capacity Advocate should be arranged in accordance with the patient's best interests
Ensure completion of the DNACPR document
Ensure clear documentation in the clinical records
Communicate the decision to other healthcare providers including the Consultant in charge
and/or GP
Review the decision if necessary
Patient

Patients who have made a decision that they would not want CPR should inform, where able, those looking after them that there is a valid documented DNACPR decision about themselves and where this can be found. Where and as appropriate the health professional can discuss ADRT process if this meets the patient's wishes.
Clinical Ward Staff
All clinical staff delivering care must:
Adhere to the policy and procedure - policy no CL02
Notify their line manager of any training needs
Sensitively enquire as to the existence of a DNACPR or an Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT)
Check the validity of any documentation
Notify other services of the DNACPR decision or an ADRT on the transfer of a person
Participate in the audit process
Policy for Decisions Regarding Attempting Cardiopulmonary
Resuscitation (CPR) for Patients CL02

The decision is specific to attempting CPR in the situation of cardio-respiratory arrest. It has no bearing on the level of active management of any other condition, nor does it refer to other aspects of care e.g. analgesia, antibiotics, suction, treatment of choking, treatment of anaphylaxis or other interventions which are sometimes loosely referred to as “resuscitation”.
It is likely to form part of an individual's treatment escalation plan.

A decision regarding CPR is specific to that situation, and each time it is made, criteria for review of the decision should also be recorded and followed. The criteria may be related to a time period or change in medical condition.
In some clinical situations, such as when the patient is in the terminal stage of a progressive life limiting illness, it may be appropriate that the decision is considered to apply indefinitely.
Training Requirements
Experienced Nurses or Allied Health Professionals
Eligible healthcare professionals must attend a uDNACPR training as specified
They must complete competencies under the observation of the Lead Clinician in their speciality area (see appendix 2)
